title: 109_hr5161
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commission on Mexican-American Removal during 1929-1941 Act". It includes findings and purpose. From 1929 through 1941, authorities forcibly removed individuals of Mexican ancestry from the United States, with as many as two million individuals sent to Mexico, including 1.2 million US citizens. This was in response to public pressure to reduce the employment of Mexican-Americans during the Depression, leading to massive raids on their communities. The raids from 1929 to 1941 targeted individuals of Mexican ancestry, labeling them as "illegal aliens" even if they were US citizens or legal residents. These actions separated families, deprived individuals of their rights and livelihoods, with no official inquiry made. The purpose of the Act is to establish a commission to investigate if US citizens and legal residents were forcibly removed to Mexico during this period. From 1929 to 1941, permanent legal residents were forcibly removed to Mexico in violation of the law. This had a significant impact on individuals, their families, and the Mexican-American community in the United States. Appropriate remedies are recommended to address this historical injustice. Establishment of a Commission named the "Commission on Mexican-American Removal during 1929-1941" to review the forced removal of US citizens and legal residents to Mexico. The Commission will examine past government directives related to these removals and submit a report with findings and recommendations to Congress. Membership details are also outlined. The Commission on Mexican-American Removal during 1929-1941 will consist of seven members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and President pro tempore of the Senate. Members must have expertise in human rights, civil rights, immigration, labor, or business. Each member serves for life, with a quorum of four members required for meetings. Members must have expertise in human rights, civil rights, immigration, labor, or business. Each member serves for life, with a quorum of four members required for meetings. The initial meeting of the Commission shall be called by the President within one hundred and twenty days after the date of the enactment of this Act, or within thirty days after the date on which legislation is enacted making appropriations to carry out this Act, whichever is later. The Commission shall elect a chairperson and vice chairperson from among its members, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Each member who is not otherwise employed by the United States shall receive compensation at a prescribed daily rate. The Commission members receive compensation at the daily rate for level IV of the Executive Schedule. Federal employees on the Commission cannot receive additional pay. Members also receive travel expenses according to specified regulations. SEC. 6. POWERS. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. They can also conduct public hearings in any city in the United States. Additionally, the Commission has the power to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to their investigations. Failure to comply with a subpoena may result in consequences. The Commission can apply to a court for an order to compel a person to testify or produce evidence related to an investigation. Failure to comply may result in civil contempt. Subpoenas are served in accordance with the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. The Commission can obtain official data from government agencies and may contract with agencies or individuals for services to carry out its duties under the Act. SEC. 7. STAFF. The Commission has the authority to appoint additional staff, including experts and consultants, and may receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. The Commission will submit a report to Congress one year after the initial meeting, detailing findings, conclusions, and legislative recommendations. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report. SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. The Commission refers to the Commission on Mexican-American Removal during 1929-1941. A member is someone on the Commission. State includes any U.S. state, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other U.S. territories.
